title: How many homicides will there be in Chicago, IL, in 2020?
preds:
I am convinced by the argumentation of @Terry-Smith which is also based on data from past years.
There are currently 787 cases according to https://heyjackass.com/# which gives more and more weight to the argument of Terry-Smith.
There are less than 3 days left. This year there were 2.17 deaths/day on average. There is a high probability that the figure will remain below 795.
Moving up to the 100, given now close to the end of the year.

No change; I'm going to remain here until the end. In particular, I'm giving 5% to deaths in Christmas+New Year+backlog of deaths.
Not my proudest question.
My original estimate of between 736 and 795 appears to have been right as 744 have been killed and there only two weeks left.
Still confused that https://heyjackass.com/ is showing a different number
Two weeks to go in the year, we stand at 727 so far. Barring a major incident I can't see the number moving above 795

Cook County data counts 24 more Chicago homicides as of Dec 8 than does the Tribune. If the Tribune later choose to include those 24, there’s still a chance (18%ish) of passing 795. So my 1% is for the possibility they retrospectively fix their count.
source ABC7chicago.com has over 700 as of December 1, 2020

According to heyjackass.com a person is shot every 11 h. [1] This means end of october there will be 755 + (16 (days left in october) * 24 h/day / 11 homicides / h) = 790. The homicide frequency seems to be decreasing so I think it is slightly more likely to have less than 795 homicides in Chicago, IL, in 2020. [1] https://heyjackass.com/#
At 735 today, so less than 736 seems impossible. according to the slider on the Chicago Tribune link, there is still 20 fewer deaths than in 2016 when it went to 795, so also very unlikely.

31 days left, 719 so far. Carrying on at same rate 2.2 a day would give us 787 still in bracket 3 I don’t think we’ll get higher that rate but think the upper bracket is still slightly in play, as a bad day day could spike it

Unfortunately, the Chicago website has not updated since Nov 9th, however we were on track to decline relative to 2016, which represented the 4th bin - thus placing the final outcome in the 3rd bin [1] [1] https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/breaking/ct-chicago-homicides-data-tracker-htmlstory.html
Deaths are 21 less than the year it hit 795. With the number of days left this year getting lower, it may be time to go all in on 736-795.
Looks like the numbers are slightly down, with a 20 homicide gap between the highest year and this year.

On the latest update of November 9th, the Tribune showed 673 homicides although the actual number through that date according to the City of Chicago was 688. Maybe there's some difference in definition (I didn't look at every entry in the csv file and compare it to the Tribune page), but in any case "Fewer than 676" has to be 0% in a city that size, unless the Tribune never updates that page again and the GJOpen simply expires this question. In 2019, there were 57 homicides from November 9 to December 31. 
In the month before November 9, 2019 there were 39 homicides. In the month before November 9, 2020, there were 71! Have to therefore assume with momentums in place that homicides from 11/9/20-12/31/20 at least match last year's for the equivalent period (and indeed, it's already ahead). So I agree with the crowd that "Between 676 and 735" is pretty much zero. The current, actual number of homicides in Chicago according to the City as of 11/18/20 is 706. The Tribune (and Sun Times) have different, lower, figures, but using the City's numbers, to hit the final outcome would require 90 homicides to occur 11/19/20-12/31/20. In 2016, Chicago had 87 homicides in the equivalent period.  Therefore I agree that the overwhelming favorite is 736-795, but I'm not quite sure I agree that "More than 795" is only 3%.

Very frustrating that the Chicago Tribune, the official source for this question, has not updated their Daily Homicide Update site since November 9th, and that their totals through the 9th have a 2 digit difference from those reported in other sources.  I suggest not using the Chicago Tribune as a source for this question in the future. The City of Chicago actually provides daily data you can download: https://data.cityofchicago.org/Public-Safety/Homicides/k9xv-yxzs but of course don't use it for this question now because it doesn't match what the Tribune reports.
Out of curiosity  I checked the wounded totals. But for poor marksmanship this forecast would be well  over 1200 already .

Exceptional 2020 year, with significant more events since covid months. Using 10 years historical figures, we see a similar behavior to 2016, which possibly slowing down faster. Using ratios of months 1-10 to 11-12, gives significant chances to the top band (unfortunately). So here pretty much a quantitative forecast using time series and seasonality though pure ETS forecast is showing significant variance, such that we put caution on the outputs there.
Is it me, or the page (https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/breaking/ct-chicago-homicides-data-tracker-htmlstory.html) hasn't updated in a while?
The rate appears to be slowing, and is already a full 10 homicides behind the year it went over 795. It looks as though it will be somewhere in the 736-795 range.

It's getting cold in Chicago, so the season's about over.   Without going to the trouble of actually checking statistics, my recollection from my Illinois years is that the rate of most crimes, including homicide, always went down when it got cold in Chicago.  You might kill people you live with during a Chicago winter, but activities for which you have to leave the house, including muggings and armed robberies and street fights, used to decline reliably starting about now. Can't think of a reason that would change.   (Full disclosure:  This argument depends on my memory, which is also declining reliably, and not on real research.)

Running Bayes gives me 26% for the third bin and 74% for the fourth bin.... Obviously, I swung pretty hard into the third bin after last week's data drop from the Chicago Tribune. The total deaths between Jan and end of October came to 673. If we hit 795 then 2020 will be the only year to do so when the totals through October are 673. The next closest was 1989 when the total through October was 677..... so, I have to conclude that I'm either doing Bayes incorrectly, that there is something I don't understand about the formula, or some other error on my part.... maybe data from November will radically change my opinion....

On track for 785, with around 2.15 homicides occurring each day. This is firmly within the 736-795 and above both historical averages and the 2016 total (the track for which the 2020 curve is currently hugging), meaning that this number is more likely to go down than up without extenuating circumstances increasing the daily numbers by about 10% for the next 50 or so days.
Rate has dropped off and we are past the time of the year that typically sees the greatest increase.
Have looked at a lot of data a lot of different ways. Basically my view is that the underlying factors that caused the homicide rate to jump in June are still with us and not going away this year.

Reran simulation using data updated through 10-24. Result is a forecast mean of 787 with 29% of forecasts coming in over 795. That is up 4% >795 from the week before.  I just noticed something very frustrating while reading  other forecasts. The Chicago Tribune, the official source for this question, reports 643 Homicides through 10-26. I have been downloading data from the City of Chicago website,  assuming it would match, but my data only goes through 10-24  and totals 654.  That is a significant discrepancy. If I assume my data has to come in 11 higher than 795 for the Tribune to show >795, my simulation only gets there 10% of the time. So I'm lowering the upper bin now, whereas I started this new forecast thinking I would be raising it. I suppose I need to find out where the Tribune gets their data...

For the last 2 months of 2020: 
Bin 1 = <11/month 
Bin 2 = 11 - <40/month 
Bin 3 = 40 - <70/month 
Bin 4 = 70 or more/month
Current trajectory: 777. With just over 2 months to go, this is almost definitely going to end up in the 736-795 bucket.

I explain this forecast with fancy charts on my new blog:
https://theclyborthcorporation.wordpress.com/2020-chicago-homicides-forecast-2/ In summary, I simulated the rest of the year by using the daily homicides from the year so far, and then adjusting the simulated days by a twenty-year seasonal trend. The mean projected is 785, with 25% of the simulated years coming in above 795. Only .01% of years came in below 736.  @cafebedouin @LokiOdinevich @PepeS @mikemobbs @bowenmjr @Jayce
Giving more deference to the aggregate.

On track to surpass 795 if rates do not slow down. Historically, the rates stay consistent throughout the year, steadily rising until the end of the year.  https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/breaking/ct-chicago-homicides-data-tracker-htmlstory.html

The slope is definitely higher than usual over the last several months. If the slope flattens out there's a slim chance it drops under 735. If it continues at the same pace the remainder of the year it would put it over 795. I'd guess it flattens out a bit making 736 to 795 most likely, but that's just based on the slope of most of the years and this one  could easily be different (and already has been much different than previous years).

According to heyjackass.com a person is shot every 10:54 h. [1] This means end of october there will be 653 + (7 (days left in october) * 24 h/day / 10,9 homicides / h) = 653 + 15 = 668. 
In 2011 84% of homicides happened until end of october. [2] 
Assuming the same distribution in 2020 we are heading for 668 / 0.84 = 795 homicides in 2020. Currently it is a draw if it will be more or less than 795 homicides in Chicago, IL, in 2020. [1] https://heyjackass.com/#
[2] https://home.chicagopolice.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/2011-Murder-Report.pdf
Updated numbers though Oct 18 increase likelihood of ending the year above 795.

I based my prediction is  based on the number of reported homicides as of Oct 9and factorerd the average month homicide rate and then made allowances for the trending increase.  https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/breaking/ct-chicago-homicides-data-tracker-htmlstory.html

605 recorded homicides this year means we are on pace to hit 761 by year's end. That's 18 less than 2 weeks ago, showing that the total is beginning to regress towards the mean. We also continue to hug the curve of 2016, which led to an eventual 762 deaths, so this projection makes even more sense.
Updated numbers for the second week of October.
Higher than 2016 this week, though barely.
I underestimated ability of Chicagoans to kill one another.
Recalculated using the 8 deaths that have occurred in October so far. I anticipate that the 4th bin will increase as more data for October comes in.
Slight uptick in probability favoring the 4th bin given how we finished September.

Skewing a bit toward the higher end. So far it's been matching 2017. Whether it hits the upward jog in November that 2017 did is the biggest question. Looking at most of the previous years the slope is lower in winter, so I would expect that to be more likely than the 2017 outlier. But this is a strange year too so it may also end up being a bit of an outlier.
Adding a bit of a pandemic premium. Rationale is from the link below. Thanks to @LokiOdinevich for raising issues with my sloppy thinking. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1149566

For the last 3 months of 2020:
Bin 1 = <29/month
Bin 2 = 29 - <49/month
Bin 3 = 49 - <69/month
Bin 4 = 69 or more/month

I thought that seasonality was going to be a thing. October came and proved me wrong. A pretty drastic dip would have to happen in order for this year to be below 735; otherwise, both @cafebedouin's less formal and @mikemobbs more formal Bayes calculation point in the same direction.
One reason why I'm not higher on the more than 795 bucket is because I may have bad priors. Another reason is that if I ask the question: Will there be more or less murders than in 2016, a 50-50 seems very appealing.

Current total is 576. Years with 550+ at end of September with year totals are listed below. Make of it what you will. 1970, 811
1971, 824
1973, 864
1974, 970
1976, 814
1979, 857
1980, 863
1981, 877
1990, 854
1991, 928
1992, 943
1993, 855
1994, 931 https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/breaking/ct-chicago-homicides-data-since-1957-20160302-htmlstory.html

A few days to go still in September and we're at 576. Updating with Bayes gives me 91% for the fourth bin. I think October's numbers will be telling, and I'm prepared to swing fully into the third bin should the numbers shift downward.

Already at 576 for 2020, currently set for 779. Regression to the mean suggests it will likely not increase too much past this mark, but it is difficult to see how we won't hit at least 735 this year with over 3 months remaining. Interestingly, current numbers are nearly identical to those in 2016, which ended with 762 homicides total, further hinting at the ultimate 736-795 outcome. https://www.cnn.com/2017/01/01/us/chicago-murders-2016/index.html

Seasonality story: After looking at seasonality, the crowd forecast seems about right; we had ~100 homicides in the summer months, but ~70 (56 so far) this September. If we see ~50 homicides/month in the winter months, we get 691. Probability implied by this view: 10/80/20/0 Year: October/November/December
2016: 83/79/58
2018: 50/46/39 Time of troubles story: @cafebedouin presents some historical data in this comment: https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1120714 but he has been known to make some confident yet wrong takes in the past. Probability implied by this scenario: 0/0/35/65 (cafebedouin gives a 25/75, but he weighs past data too strongly, IMHO; DNA evidence wasn't available until relatively late. I'm giving more weight to the thought that "40/60 that it will be more than in 2016") Aggregating both: 5/40/27/33 The aggregate is at ~0/23/62/15. One explanation is that the two forces (social unrest and lower expected winter murders) point in different directions, so we shouldn't see either extreme, but a mix of the two. Taken the aggregate into account produces something like: 2/25/48/25 What will convince me to change my opinion: if September/October keep having higher homicide rates than 2016, I'll move more probability mass to the last bucket. Conversely, if they have homicide rates closer to 2019, I'll move more towards the first buckets. If they're right in the middle, I'll add to the middle.
Time to ditch my optimism. Nod to @cafebedouin
Increase of 20 to 558 for September. Adjusting inputs to Bayes to update forecast.

Depleting fewer than 676 possibility, appears like probability of that is negligible. In 2017 there were 166 homicides from now until year end. That would put it at 538 + 166 = 704 homicides at the end of the year. I think it's more likely that the lower slopes of previous years is followed than the steeper slope of 2016, which looks like a bit of an outlier. Of course, this year is an outlier as far as major events goes, so low confidence in that.

- Numbers in September (up to 09/10) again increased to around 20% above 2015-2019 average
- Data point toward >770
Increasing my very low probabilities a little bit, because I realize I'm not really that well calibrated for low percentages.

Currently a rate of 2.1 per day and 546 in total [1]if this stayed steady we would be looking at  772 at year end. Historically rates have slowed in the winter months but if this dropped to 1.8 tomorrow it would still be in the 736 and 795 bracket, so would need to slow very significantly later in the year or start to slow very soon. [1] https://graphics.suntimes.com/homicides/ side note does the chicago tribune link in the question work for anyone else? i just see an empty page
Updated to 538 as of September 13, increased probability of surpassing 795 for the year.
My optimism Appears to have been misplaced in near term (538 to date). Regardless still going low.

Current pace puts the total around 773, a significant uptick from historic averages but a forecast well in-line with current trends (no large-scale event driving the totals). A regression to the mean is possible, if unlikely, but given the sustained elevated levels thus far it seems more probable that we end the year comfortably within the 736 and 795 range. I'd guess in the 750s.

539 total as of 11am September 13.
Approximate monthly numbers through year end to hit specific bins:
>676 = 39
>735 = 56
>795 = 73
+5 to 676 and 735 category and -5 to 736 and 795 category, looks like it's tracking along the higher 2016 trend right now.
Update for the week brings us to 523 (21 for the first week of September). Adjusting accordingly.
Slightly below crowd because I'm assuming the seasonal pattern will hold.
Moving in deference to the median.

Currently every 11:14h a person is shot. [1] So far 537 homicides happened. A simple projection assuming the same pace until the end of the months returns 566 homicides until the end of the month. In 2011 73% of homicides happened until end of september. [2] Assuming the same distribution in 2020 we are heading for 775 homicides in 2020. As the pace increases I also raise the likelihood to hit bucket [797,inf)  [1] https://heyjackass.com/#
[2] https://home.chicagopolice.org/wp-content/uploads/2014/12/2011-Murder-Report.pdf

https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/local/chicago-murders-and-shootings-up-overall-crime-down-halfway-through-2020-police-say/2298155/ In the first half year of 2020 the homicide rate was 34% up compared to the year before. There have been 506 homicides last year.

We are at 514 as of 3rd September. This is 2.08 per day for 2020 to date. In my last forecast about a month ago or so it was 2.06 per day. So the pace is keeping up. Checking whether it will cross the first threshold of 676: 676-514=162 in the next 119 days remaining in 2020. That is 1.36 per day. Very low and almost certain to be surpassed. So 0% for the first bracket. Checking whether the 735 will be surpassed: 735-514=221 more homicides in 119 days. That is 1.86. It seems pretty likely that it will be surpassed. I leave a small 10% for a potential slow down on the pace of homicides but not likely. Checking whether 795 will be surpassed: 795-514=281 more homicides in 119 days that is 2.36 a rather high pace. Not likely, I assign 0%. Projected number is 514+(119x2.08)=761 homicides with a variation of 30 homicides which is 0.25 per day. Put us square in the middle of the third bracket. So I assign all my 90% to that and leave 10% for a potential significant slow down.
I like the contrast between @Dogopotamus's inside view and @cafebedouin's historical base rate. August figures were not clarifying. Interesting that the last election year (2016) had so many deaths.

The count for August was 62 (assuming no homicides  are recorded in the next 2.5 hours). This is a reduction of 45 (42%) from July and 32.67 (35%) of the average for May/June/July. If the remaining 4 months of 2020 average 62, the total for the year will be 743. I believe they’ll average closer to 45-50, placing the total firmly in Bucket #2.
https://graphics.suntimes.com/homicides/
Slight tweak up given the recent bleak numbers. Still haven’t had a chance to recalibrate completely.
Chicago website updated Sunday's total so we're at 497 for the year (58 for August). Plugged updated numbers in to Bayes and got 15% and 85%.

Data from: https://data.cityofchicago.org/Public-Safety/Homicides/k9xv-yxzs - Since 2001: minimum of 426, average of 529 - With 448 homicides by end of July, projection calculated from correlation between these two time points in the last 19 years, yields a 2020 final number of around 790 - With respect to previous 19 years, large spikes appeared in June and July (approx. 100% increase). If this trend continues, numbers higher than 795 quite likely. - However, if numbers regress back to mean sooner than later, numbers lower than 795 likely outcome - Update: Large shift compared to last forecasts. Data until August 22nd suggest that August numbers are closer to 20 year average. With an assumed regression to the mean, numbers below 795 become much more probable.

At current rates, the homicide count would reach the third bucket due to a recent uptick in the area. However, historical averages predict this year will end closer to 722, which falls well within the second bucket. I lean more towards the historical averages than the current pace, but it appears the other 2 buckets are becoming less likely by the day.

So I was right!!!! I did miscalculate using Bayes Formula in my earlier forecast......  specifically in how I calculated P(B|A), or the probability of at least 485 deaths in August given any of the 4 conditions in the challenge (<676, 676-735, 736-795, >795).... Once correcting for that error I'm left with 22% and 78% for the top two brackets.  This will update as the Chicago Tribune website updates.
Updating had a error in my calculation before
Small update based on current trajectory at 1.97 a day. I need to do a full recalibration on this soon

As of August 16th the number of homicides 2020 is equal to the number of homicides committed in 2016. [1] My current forecast for 2020 is a total of 760 homicides in Chicago.
In 2016 the total number of homicides in Chicago were 762. [2]   When assuming that the distribution is equal or similar to the one in 2011 then 64% of homicides [3] happened until end of August. The current number of homicides is 491. If 491 is 64% then 100% is 765. This too increases the probability for range [736,795]. Therefore increasing the probability for the range [736,795] to 75%. [1] https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/breaking/ct-chicago-homicides-data-tracker-htmlstory.html
[2] https://time.com/4635049/chicago-murder-rate-homicides/
[3] https://time.com/4635049/chicago-murder-rate-homicides/
[4] https://heyjackass.com/#

Based on the Chicago data it looks to me like the killing of George Floyd (on May 25) was the spark for the jump in homicides. That pushed the trend up to a new level, but I think the rest of the year will follow a similar slope as previous years now that time has passed and things may have calmed down a bit. In my opinion the likely range is between 2016 and 2017 looking at the chart at the Chicago Tribune. I'm leaning toward the lower end of that range just based on the last two years and that 2017 looks like it may have been an outlier in the rate of homicides at the tail end of the year.

Upping a little to 736-795 because of current rates placing ultimate total projection around 735. Still believe regression to mean and police crackdowns will lead to lower ultimate rates, but the figures thus far are not reflecting my initial assumptions. Will update in coming weeks.
New stats till Augusts = 440. Same rate = 755 for the year.

In 2020 every 11:32h a person is murdered in chicago. [1]
If the killing continues with that pace there will be (24*365/11,53=) 760 killed persons at the end of 2020. Therefore increasing the probability for the range [736,795]. [1] https://heyjackass.com/#

467 homicides as of August 21st (234 days into 2020). That’s 1.99 per day = projection for 730 in the year. I decided to focus on the brackets 1&2 around 730. It has slowed down since my last update when it was 2.06 per day at end of July. So I’ll add significantly more probability to the 676-735 bracket than I had before. The bracket containing the current projection based on the current rate (1.99 per day = 730 total) should have the majority of the probability. Though the border is set at just five homicides more (at 735) so the higher bracket is very likely too.
Leaving a small 10% only due to the slowing down that is observed.
Small revision downward as recently we have seen a reduction toward previous years rate

Data from: https://data.cityofchicago.org/Public-Safety/Homicides/k9xv-yxzs - Since 2001: minimum of 426, average of 529 - With 448 homicides by end of July, projection calculated from correlation between these two time points in the last 19 years, yields a 2020 final number of around 790 - With respect to previous 19 years, large spikes appeared in June and July (approx. 100% increase). If this trend continues, numbers higher than 795 quite likely. - However, if numbers regress back to mean sooner than later, numbers lower than 795 likely outcome - Update: Data until August 11th suggest that August numbers are close to 20 year average. Slight correction of forecast towards 736 and 795
Changing my mind on this as the past 3 weeks has reverted to the mean.

I'm using Bayes Formula to calculate this, and I'm sure that I'm off here.... but first, a shout out to @mkamuda for linking me to the historical data going back to 1957, and a thanks to @cafebedouin for providing it. So I looked at each condition in order to find my priors: P1(A): In a given year there is a  0.555555556 chance of fewer than 676 deaths
P2(A): In a given year there is a  0.079365079 chance of between 676 and 735 deaths
P3(A): In a given year there is a  0.095238095 chance of between 736 and 795 deaths
P4(A): In a given year there is a  0.26984127 chance of greater than 795 deaths P(B): Probability that at least 438 total deaths by July.  = .2857143 *********I've corrected for how I calculate all P(B|A) in my latest forecast, what I have here is incorrect**********
P1(B|A) = probability that 438 total deaths by July resulted in fewer than 676 deaths for the year = 0%
P2(B|A) = probability that 438 total deaths by July resulted in between 676 and 735 deaths for the year = 0%
P3(B|A) = probability that 438 total deaths by July resulted in between 736 and 795 deaths for the year = 0%
P4(B|A) = probability that 438 total deaths by July resulted in at least 795 deaths = 94.444% The first three conditions result in a 0% probability, but the final condition results in 89.1975309% probability.  This is why I'm adjusting to 89% for greater than 795 deaths for the year. What I don't know is what to actually do with the remaining 11%. I've spread it out over the 2nd and 3rd condition ,1% and 10% respectively, but I have no mathematical reason to do so. If someone else out there who better understands Bayes wants to weigh in, I'd be very appreciative. Adding this link for my own reference to compare with Chicago Tribune data: https://heyjackass.com/
The push back and defunding of the police coupled with social tensions and mass unemployment due to Covid restrictions make it likely that violence will increase to beyond previously seen levels.
Giving more weight to a regression back to the mean.

This is a really poor forecast, made simply by looking at how the current death toll of 464 compares to the data available at the Chicago Tribune website. I'm quite sure that there is a math driven way to arrive at a reasonable projection.... but that's a project for this week!

With 440 homicides until end of July, that is 2.07 per day for the 213 days of the year so far.
We have 153 days remaining in 2020, from end of July.
Thus, assuming steady pace of homicides, we can extrapolate to 756 for the year.
Having said that, the high pace of the first 7 months of 2020 doesn't necessarily mean it will keep up the same, and could slow down (since it is a high pace, I am less inclined to believe that it could further accelerate, although it might still).
A pace of 1.54 homicides per day from Aug 1st onwards is what would be required to get to 676 homicides, which is the divider between the two brackets. This is a pace that is 25% less than the pace of homicides in the year to date. I find that, while the pace can definitely get slower, it will be hard to get to something much slower (e.g. 30% or 40% slower pace). So I tend to believe that the second bracket is more plausible. If the pace stays between a decrease by 7%, to 1.93 homicides per day, and an increase of up to +12% to about 2.32 homicides per day, then we are in the third bracket. Now if the pace increases, to 2.32 (+12% faster pace than so far), we cross into the fourth bracket. I don't assign much probability to an even faster homicide pace, so I will choose between 5% or 0%. Looked at the past years' homicide totals:
https://edition.cnn.com/2017/01/02/us/chicago-murder-rate-2016-visual-guide/index.html
And produced a Normal Distribution around these 20 years (from 2001-2019). The mean is just 1.43 and the standard deviation is 0.27. The standard deviation of the years that had the most homicides is not much different. I will use the standard deviation of 0.27, on the 756 extrapolated homicides for 2020. 676 total homicides for 2020 means 236 in the remaining 153 days (1.54 rate per day), which is much less than the year-so-far homicides rate of 2.06 (projecting to 756 total homicides). That is a dramatic drop for the remainder of the year and not very likely. I believe the normal distribution is skewed towards the left (towards lower homicides) because the pace is more likely to slow down than it is to speed up. So I will allocate 10% to the first bracket. 735 total homicides is 295 in the remainder of 2020 (1.93 rate per day). Still it is a slow down of 0.13 per day (-7% from current 2020 rate), which is half a standard deviation lower than the 2.06. That places it in the 31% probability (of total up to 735). Subtracting the 10% probability I assigned to the "below 676" bracket, leaves me with another 21% for the bracket of 676-735. The 795 homicides represents another 355 for the remainder of the year (2.32 rate per day). That is a significant increase, up from the already high outlier homicide rate of 2.06 we have seen in this year so far. Quite unlikely I would say, being about one standard deviation higher. This, applied on a normal distribution around 2.06 rate, gives me a probability of 16%. Considering a significant downwards skew (again, I believe the current high homicides rate can decrease but not as likely to increase), therefore I will round down the probability to 10% or even 5%. I choose 5% by intuition. The remaining 65% for the middle bracket, which (as a sense check):
- contains the current extrapolated projection of 756, approximately smack in the middle.
- on the low end is bordered by 736, which is 1.93 for the remainder of the year, or 2.01 overall rate in the year.
- on the high end is bordered by 795, which is 2.32 for the remainder of the year, or 2.17 overall rate in the year.
Sounds like the most likely outcome.

There are currently 452 homicides in Chicago for 2020 (https://graphics.suntimes.com/homicides/), meaning the projection is now around 733 homicides for the year, around 7 less than my projection 2 weeks ago. The mean for Chicago has been 675 historically, so the number will likely continue regressing toward the mean for the remainder of the year. Evidence suggests homicides increase around holidays, which we still have quite a few of this year, but those spikes are unlikely to have a notable impact on the overall count. With the federal government now taking an interest in the increasing crime rate and potentially looking to interfere, it is also unlikely the rate will continue of increase by years end. Really, its going to come down to a natural rate towards the years end, and predicting that is going to come down to historic norms, which suggest the second bucket.

To get a prior using https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/breaking/ct-chicago-homicides-data-tracker-htmlstory.html: import numpy as np
from scipy.stats import norm
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
total_homicides = [445, 448, 494, 795, 676, 573, 519]
mu, std = norm.fit(total_homicides)
_ = plt.hist(total_homicides, bins=5, density=True, alpha=0.6, color='g')
xmin, xmax = plt.xlim()
x = np.linspace(xmin, xmax, 100)
p = norm.pdf(x, mu, std)
plt.plot(x, p, 'k', linewidth=2) print(str(mu - std)[0:3] + ' <---> ' + str(mu + std)[0:3] + ' 68%')

Chicago had 440 Homicides recorded as of July 31st, while during the same period last year there were only 290 homicides, so an increase of 150 or about 50%. In 2016, the most violent recent year, there were 780 homicides, and Chicago has already surpassed them on a YDT basis (440 vs 404).  Fewer than 676: that would mean less than 236 in the next 5 months. At the current rate of 63 shootings per month on average, that seems wildly unlikely.
676 - 735: I think that is possible, but only with some fundamental shifts in the trend. That would require fewer than 59 homicides a month, an overall reduction on a monthly basis, while we have been seeing an increase. 
735 - 795: If the YDT rate continues, this is where we will end up. However, since rates increased sharply in March, if that rate continues we will overshoot 795. I think it is reasonably likely to finish in this range, if the lock down ends and rates fall again. Of course, that assumes that the homicide rate is directly and immediately correlated with the lock down. 
795+: This seems the most likely. Using 2016 as a comparison, it seems reasonable to expect that we will conclude the year with levels higher than theirs (that is, higher than 780), and that we will likely surpass 795. https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/criminal-justice/ct-chicago-violence-2019-results-20200101-xqrtozhu3zgbpjiopwaaujjcgq-story.html
https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/breaking/ct-chicago-homicides-data-tracker-htmlstory.html

I'm looking at the Chicago homicide dataset (https://data.cityofchicago.org/Public-Safety/Homicides/k9xv-yxzs). The first thing to note, as many have already done, is that we're already at a 20-year record for Homicides before August 1st. If people stopped being murdered today, we'd already be in the 25th percentile for ANNUAL homicides in Chicago. The other thing to consider is that, in 90% of the past twenty years, homicides-by-August-1st have constituted roughly between 50 and 60% of all the murders in a given year. So I'd say with some 90% confidence (based on this base rate alone) that 440 constitutes between 50% and 60% of this year's homicides. So: 90% confidence that the total number of homicides will fall between 730 and 880. Specificity in the upper end of my estimate is derived by bootstrapping, lower end by peanut-buttering.

Currently at 432 homicides, statistical data shows an average of about 240 more deaths in the remaining months. That total would bring us to about 670 (in a typical year.) This year is already smashing last years total homicides, so I  multiplied the 240 by 1.5 to get 360, this would bring the total to 792. I’m leaving a higher percent for over 795 because the numbers are already so high.

Let me show my convoluted math. I want to calculate numbers for the remaining 5 months using the assumption the rate will stay the same as it has for June and July but adjusting for seasonal factors, since summer months tend to be worse than cooler months.  Looking at seasonal stats here: https://www.chicagomag.com/Chicago-Magazine/The-312/March-2012/Heat-and-Crime-Its-Not-Just-You-Feeling-It/ I find that homicides in June + July account for 34% of all homicides for the last 7 months of the year. So I divide 194 (homicides for June + July in 2020) by .34 and get 568.  There were 246 homicides at the end of May. 246 + 568 = 814.  To recap, I view the year as divided into 2 parts: pre-protests and post-protests. The murder rate has shot up post-protests, so I am adding the pre-protest months to the post-protest months to reach an estimated total.  Hopefully I am wrong about the homicide rate remaining elevated and will have to adjust my numbers down a lot at the end of August.

Chicago has the highest number of gang members in any city in the US and 80% of murders there are gang related. The gangs are not thought to be only driven by criminal economic activity but act "revolve around identity and solidarity among young people who find themselves in similar circumstances and share an identification with a particular neighbourhood."(3).  Combining this with an increased need for protection in the face of the rising crime rate it is fair to say that more people will be incentivised to join gangs. If the police are not able for whatever reason to arrest this increase (and thus far they have not) then it is likely the cycle of violence will continue.  To move onto numbers, @Calgacus has come up with "5 months at 2 a day - 813, 5 months at 1.3 - 701, 3 months 2 then 2 at 1.3 - 759".  There are some potential lower likelihood events that could push the numbers way up; a particularly deadly mass shooting ala the las vegas shooting if someone attacks a funeral with a greater arsenal than is currently being used. If hospitals became overwhelmed due to a spike in cases of coronavirus emergency rooms could become less effective and save fewer of those who are shot. If there is a protest movement which manages to remove police enforcement entirely from an area, like we saw in Seattle, then this could also have an impact. If there is earlier than usual cold weather this could also reduce the amount of homicides. A change in leadership or methods by the CPD before the end of the year is a possibility. A very sad question in which I hope the eventual number is as low as possible. 1/https://chicago.suntimes.com/crime/2020/7/22/21334970/gang-feud-mass-shooting-funeral-home-auburn-gresham 2/https://news.wttw.com/2020/07/27/critics-say-chicago-police-need-rethink-tracking-gang-members-curbing-violence 3/https://www.thetrace.org/2020/07/chicago-gang-gun-violence-law-enforcement/

Base case is 2019 with ~500 homicides.
Statistics first half year of 2020 is 329 homicides. With June scoring 75% higher than last year. When you take the next half year of homicides with the same increase of 75% compared to last year, that's 438 homicides. Plus the homicides already committed is 767. With a margin error of 50 you will get a case of 5%-25%-45%-25%. Is the 75% increase realistic? With the current economic outlook for the US and especially the mid-west you will see this correlation. That in combination with the segregation between black and white in the city of Chicago and the politics around black lives matter, I would say 75% increase is a good estimate. https://chicago.suntimes.com/crime/2020/7/1/21309399/june-crime-stats-chicago-police-david-brown-homicides-murders

https://www.nbcchicago.com/news/local/chicago-murders-and-shootings-up-overall-crime-down-halfway-through-2020-police-say/2298155/ Here it says 329 till and of June. May June and July are the peak months. So, extrapolating this would give approximately 660 homicides.
But recent years the homicides were below 500, so this is an abnormality (specific increase/maybe gang wars/perhaps concentrated in the early months of the year) or an increase of homicides due to a new more violent reality (i.e. change of behavior, something that is expected to affect the rest of the year).
I would be interested to see the time stamp of these homicides, if they are spread evenly, then it is a more violent year overall, if it is concentrated in a particular month, then it is something that we can’t extrapolate to the entire year. Until then, I tend to believe that increase in the first half of the year has no reason to be an increase for the second half of the year as well. I will go with assuming the rest of 2020 goes like the yearly average (up to 500 homicides per year, thus 250 for half year) rather than a repeat of the former half.
I will add 300 to the 329 of the first half which takes me to ~630. I just cannot justify those 700 homicide brackets of the question. I will allocate my probabilities around the 676 with more weight on the “under”.

The US murder rate is about 5 in 100,000 people, which is around 0.005%. This is equivalent to about 135 deaths in Chicago. However, the murder rate in Chicago is markedly higher, so this will serve as a lower limit. Since 1985, the average murder rate in Chicago is around 25 in 100,000 residents, or about 675 homicides per year. This will serve as a historic mean. The highest rate on record is about 0.33%, or 891 homicides in a single year. At the end of June this year, Chicago was on pace for 658 murders despite a large uptick since last year, where there were a little over 500 for the entire year. As of July 29th, there were 432 murders, putting the projection at 740 for the year. A lot are in the news right now given the federal response, but the surge isn't unprecedented and will likely slow down. Odds are, the year will close out a close to the 676 mark, probably a little higher.
